page.title: 12PAKEFIELD BEACH AND FISHING
page.content: The foreshore at Pakefield has built up considerably over the past 20 years as a consequence of the construction of wooden groynes to prevent the erosion of the beach and cliff by the sea. This foreshore is made up almost entirely of shingle which slopes steeply down to the sea and which is, on average, some 200 metres in width from the cliff to the sea. On the foreshore is kept the local fleet of some 50 longshore boats, so called because they are used for {fishing} along the shore.The boats are mostly of wood, are clinker built and are about 5 to 8 metres in length. They are launched from the {beach} over short wooden planks known as 'skeets'. Having rowed through the breakers the fishermen start the outboard motor. They catch cod and whiting by long lining, trawl for shrimps, soles and dabs and use drift nets for herring.
